Award.AbstractNarration:
Waddington/1246045

This award supports a project to investigate the onset and growth of folds and other disturbances seen in the stratigraphic layers of polar ice sheets. The intellectual merit of the work is that it will lead to a better understanding of the grain-scale processes that control the development of these stratigraphic features in the ice and will help answer questions such as what processes can initiate such disturbances. Snow is deposited on polar ice sheets in layers that are generally flat, with thicknesses that vary slowly along the layers. However, ice cores and ice-penetrating radar show that in some cases, after conversion to ice, and following lengthy burial, the layers can become folded, develop pinch-and-swell structures (boudinage), and be sheared by ice flow, at scales ranging from centimeters to hundreds of meters. The processes causing these disturbances are still poorly understood. Disturbances appear to develop first at the ice-crystal scale, then cascade up to larger scales with continuing ice flow and strain. Crystal-scale processes causing distortions of cm-scale layers will be modeled using Elle, a microstructure-modeling package, and constrained by fabric thin-sections and grain-elongation measurements from the West Antarctic Ice Sheet divide ice-core. A full-stress continuum anisotropic ice-flow model coupled to an ice-fabric evolution model will be used to study bulk flow of anisotropic ice, to understand evolution and growth of flow disturbances on the meter and larger scale. Results from this study will assist in future ice-core site selection, and interpretation of stratigraphy in ice cores and radar, and will provide improved descriptions of rheology and stratigraphy for ice-sheet flow models.The broader impacts are that it will bring greater understanding to ice dynamics responsible for stratigraphic disturbance. This information is valuable to constrain depth-age relationships in ice cores for paleoclimate study. This will allow researchers to put current climate change in a more accurate context. This project will provide three years of support for a graduate student as well as support and research experience for an undergraduate research assistant; this will contribute to development of talent needed to address important future questions in glaciology and climate change. The research will be communicated to the public through outreach events and results from the study will be disseminated through public and professional meetings as well as journal publications. The project does not require field work in Antarctica.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Ice in Earth’s glaciers is composed of many small crystals. The weight of overlying ice combined with a slope in the glacier’s surface causes the crystals to deform, causing the ice to slowly flow. However, the deformation of an individual crystal depends on that crystal’s orientation with respect to the stress driving the flow. Crystals do not deform the same in all directions. Each crystal has a direction known as the c-axis. Perpendicular to this direction, the ice deforms easily like a deck of cards. However, deformation in other orientations is many times more difficult.

 

If ice crystals are randomly oriented, then bulk ice made up of many crystals still deforms isotropically, or the same, in every direction. However, the crystals rotate in response to deformation, with the c-axes tending to line up in directions where there is compression, thus producing overall anisotropic deformation. In vertical compression, this makes the ice hard overall, since the c-axes will line up vertically. In this case, this is like trying to compress a deck of cards by pressing down on it. In horizontal simple shear, the combination of compression and rotation also causes the c-axes to line up vertically, but this makes the ice soft: it is like sliding cards past each other.

 

Thus, anisotropy has an enormous effect on ice flow, but ice flow also strongly affects anisotropy. Understanding the physics of this system is thus critical to understanding ice flow, especially in the large ice sheets of Antarctica and Greenland.

 

Our work has helped shed light on this problem from several angles. The orientations of crystals, or the crystal orientation fabric, has usually been measured from thin sections taken from ice cores. However, these thin sections only have a limited number of grains, so determining larger-scale fabric is subject to significant error. We developed new estimates of this error in determining fabric in thin sections, so that measurements can be interpreted with the appropriate level of confidence.

 

 The problem of error from small sample-size in thin-section measurements of fabric can be ameliorated by instead measuring the speed of sound waves in the ice, but this is subject to bias due to inaccuracies in instrumentation. We developed a way to combine these two methods of measurement to produce fabric estimates more accurate than either method in isolation. This helps us to better understand the effects of fabric on ice flow, and even gain information on past climate from the fabric.

 

The climate of Earth’s past is critical to understanding the effects of climate change on Earth’s present and future, and the most valuable records of past climate are from measurements taken from ice cores. However, this requires that the ice can be accurately dated. In the upper portions of ice sheets, the ice is nicely layered, with older ice below younger ice. Deeper, however, and these layers often become jumbled or even pinched out.  This makes interpreting past climate from this ice very difficult or impossible, since the determination of age becomes difficult. Much of this may be due to the coupling of fabric and ice flow. Since fabric affects flow, and vice-versa, small initial differences in fabric could become reinforced, causing larger spatial differences in flow, thus causing the initial differences in fabric to grow even more.

 

To investigate this possibility, we developed a flow model for ice with anisotropic fabric, and coupled it to a model of fabric development. We showed that some kinds of initial fabric perturbations can become reinforced by flow. We showed that “shear bands” can develop under our model, which can invert layers, putting younger ice below older ice. While our model cannot be used to “unfold” jumbled ice, greater understanding of the processes behind layer disturbances could lead to ways of reducing their negative effects on interpretation of past climate in ice cores.
